contents.title: About
contents.content_html:
Come join us at Permacomputing Club where we explore how to make tech more sustainable. This is an in-person meetup. We gather on a drop-in basis, but if you'd like to RSVP, feel free! - https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/permacomputing-club-tickets-1317345117709

For the sessions, we started focusing on discussion rather than independent tinkering. We tend to go around the group and share something we have read, experienced, or a project we're working on that we want to get feedback on. This crit-based approach enables everyone to give advice a share knowledge while foregrounding reflection and critique.

SET has karaoke in the Red Bar after the meeting so feel free to stay longer for some entertainment!
contents.description_html:
A community gathering dedicated to permacomputing – cultivating resilient, and sustainable approaches to technology. Share your skills, explore regenerative and low-tech computing, and practice hands-on maintenance and repair. This is a space to collaborate and discuss how hardware and software can prioritise adaptability, transparency and care. At a time when harmful tech practices like AI are dominating culture, we want to build a community in opposition to this. Everyone is welcome but we encourage women and non-binary folks to join us. Please bring your own tech, and take a moment to read our principles before joining: https://permacomputing.net/Principles.

Date: Every Monday

Time: 6:30 - 7:30 pm

Location: SET Social (55a Nigel Rd, London SE15 4NP)

Pin: top

Border: #FF0000

contents.title: Propagation
contents.content_html:
Headline: anti-real-time, navigation via svg

![Spotted Begonia in three pots](https://ixi4jeb43ehhpm46.s3.amazonaws.com/ana/20250331_160810682-min.jpg)

There was no sign of nodes until 6 weeks after the stems were cut (which is late!), at which point I lost patience and planted them in soil with the tiniest roots, hoping for the best. They persevered! They are growing, and their leaves look healthy. I'm astonished to have grown three plants from one seemingly sensitive and high-maintenance Spotted Begonia.

I thought of Rowan Markson's piece "Adventitious Roots" that looks at the "adventitious and rhizomatic potential of the Tradescantia Zebrina plant". We published the site together and released his research in segments/leaves, and as such the website would grow. Rowan posting discoveries in blog form was inspired by the plant's motions, challenging real-time culture by proposing the release of information via seasonal impact or creeping, intermittent and volatile progress. The website is navigated by clicking SVG colours of the scanned plant to open posts, and visitors sweep through Rowan's findings by literally exploring the plant's delineation.

adventitiousroots.net
contents.content:
Headline: anti-real-time, navigation via svg

----

![Spotted Begonia in three pots](https://ixi4jeb43ehhpm46.s3.amazonaws.com/ana/20250331_160810682-min.jpg)

There was no sign of nodes until 6 weeks after the stems were cut (which is late!), at which point I lost patience and planted them in soil with the tiniest roots, hoping for the best. They persevered! They are growing, and their leaves look healthy. I'm astonished to have grown three plants from one seemingly sensitive and high-maintenance Spotted Begonia. 

I thought of Rowan Markson's piece "Adventitious Roots" that looks at the "adventitious and rhizomatic potential of the Tradescantia Zebrina plant". We published the site together and released his research in segments/leaves, and as such the website would grow. Rowan posting discoveries in blog form was inspired by the plant's motions, challenging real-time culture by proposing the release of information via seasonal impact or creeping, intermittent and volatile progress. The website is navigated by clicking SVG colours of the scanned plant to open posts, and visitors sweep through Rowan's findings by literally exploring the plant's delineation. 

[adventitiousroots.net](https://www.adventitiousroots.net/)
contents.description:
Tags: plants, navigation

Author: Ana

Colour: #cf96e8

Border: #008000

contents.title: Update: CMS
contents.content_html: This website currently uses Are.na as our CMS, but we're looking to transition to a more decentralised system (Mastodon API?). For more info on this, see our source code and readme: https://github.com/anmeisel/permacomputing-club. If you have ideas, advice, or would like to help with the CMS swap, please raise this in one of our sessions or email ana@4us4others.com ❀

contents.title: Screening
contents.content_html:
I'd quite like to put on a screening of computer art films as part of the club.

I don't have too much of a plan yet, but I figure we would want it to run for about an hour, so just off the top of my head:

  • 'Network Topology' (Margot McEwen, 2024, 11 mins) - this is my movie
  • 'UFOs' (Lillian Schwartz, 1971, 3 mins) - all her films are very short so we could do a couple
  • 'Cityscape' (Michael Snow, 2019, 8 mins)
  • 'The Matter' (Woody and Steina Vasulka, 1974, 4 mins) - again these are very short so we could do a couple

If anyone else would like to show one of their own films, or just has any ideas then let me know!
contents.description_html:
Author: Margot

Colour: Beige

Border: DarkGreen

The very start of a plan for putting on a screening of computer art films as part of the club

contents.title: Day out - symposium and conference
contents.content_html:
If anyone would like to join us on a little trip to:

  • Material Memory Symposium at the Photographers Gallery: https://thephotographersgallery.org.uk/whats-on/symposium-material-memory-and-ai-archive on the 3rd of July
  • Infrastructure + Methodological Diversity keynote at London South Bank University for the Digital x Data Research Centre conference: https://www.centreforthestudyof.net/digitalxdata/ on the 4th of July

Email Em and we’ll get a group together.

contents.content_html:
• Decided to take minutes!
  • Discussion of the content of Margo's upcoming screening: she would like to fill the extra time with other submissions from the group / historical works.
  • Updates on Joe's screaming computer project: running a local LLM screams the loudest so far.
  • (Obligatory Algorave/Algorythms chat)
  • Tom explained his work with housing campaigns: aggregating data from (laborious) FOI requests, the potential for "useful art" in combating housing crises.
  • (Obligatory grep jokes)
  • Nick explained his capstone project as part of the UCL Public History Master's, and shared his highlights from the history of the LINC project. Stay tuned for his exhibition this September!
  • Updates on the printer hacking project: everyone seems keen to try making our own inks...
  • Retro-computing chat. Mat picked up a Macintosh SE to refurbish, but doesn't have access to his tools for the foreseeable future.
  • The National Museum of Computing vs. The Centre for Computing History: fight.

contents.content_html:
Notes for Permacomputing Club - 07.07.25

Changes to Website

  • Potentially changing web host to leaflet.pub
  • Ana wants to redesign site to be more grid based
  • Nick suggested side notes (looking for link)

Liberating a Printer

  • HP Deskjet 3055a - manual(s)
  • Daniel brought in a printer and oscilloscope, so we could have a look at capturing and modifying signals sent by the printer
  • Ana talked to someone about 'inkcap mushrooms' which we could try to grow
  • Nick also suggested iron gall ink, but it burns the paper
  • There is an option on the webserver settings to disable cartridge protection
  • We're in!
  • Printers fingerprint every page you print with yellow dots, that can be used to track every page back to the printer it came from
  • Yellow ink comes from 'gamboge' - a sap collected from the killing fields of Cambodia

Nick - Show and Tell - OLPC

  • Nick has 4 'One Laptop per Child' laptops!
  • One of them still works
  • OS runs in a virtual machine
  • OLPC website
contents.content:
# Notes for Permacomputing Club - 07.07.25

## Changes to Website

- Potentially changing web host to [leaflet.pub](https://about.leaflet.pub)
- Ana wants to redesign site to be more grid based
- Nick suggested side notes (looking for link)

## Liberating a Printer

- HP Deskjet 3055a - [manual(s)](https://support.hp.com/us-en/product/setup-user-guides/hp-deskjet-3050a-e-all-in-one-printer-series-j611/model/5224265)
- Daniel brought in a printer and oscilloscope, so we could have a look at
capturing and modifying signals sent by the printer
- Ana talked to someone about 'inkcap mushrooms' which we could try to grow
- Nick also suggested iron gall ink, but it burns the paper
- There is an option on the webserver settings to disable cartridge protection
- **We're in!**
- Printers fingerprint every page you print with yellow dots, that can be used
to track every page back to the printer it came from
- Yellow ink comes from 'gamboge' - a sap collected from the killing fields of Cambodia

## Nick - Show and Tell - OLPC

- Nick has 4 'One Laptop per Child' laptops!
- One of them still works
- OS runs in a virtual machine
- [OLPC website](https://laptop.org/)
contents.description:
Tags: notes
Border: IndianRed
Colour: LavenderBlush

contents.title: Notes for 2025-07-14
contents.content_html:
Text Adventures

Nick shared some PunyInform work he did with the CS department at University of Minnesota Duluth. Their cybersecurity programme uses a text adventure written by postgraduates to test undergraduates' ability to exploit physical security vulnerabilities.

  • Live playable game
  • source code

Cameras

Nick gave Margot a spare Cisco/NXP digital camera from circa 2012 to play with, in case it was useful. It has a glorious flip-out USB 2.0 plug, and a dastardly mini-HDMI socket. It also runs off AA batteries (packaged separately, so the alkaline crust was contained in the shrinkwrap!). It doesn't expose live video through the USB port, but perhaps the HDMI port could be a way to get a video stream.

Printer

Dan brought the printer back out, and we learned that it was possibly running some sort of embedded Linux inside. There are hopes of an exploit to get into the thing, but also there are approaches to defeat the self-disabling features of the cartridges themselves: https://hackaday.com/2024/09/28/man-in-the-middle-pcb-unlocks-hp-ink-cartridges/

The printer hosts its own WiFi network in the hall, which you need to switch to in order to poke at the submission port. It runs its own service called "HP GGW", which was easily crashed in fuzz testing.

We talked about various vegetable pigments to make custom inks (as inkcap mushrooms are too toxic to work with casually just yet).

CMS

Ana looked into alternatives that were more distributed, but the https://leaflet.pub project seems to be in a suspicious state regarding licensing and governance. This group would likely find raw git and markdown comfortable, but it presents an accessibility barrier to incoming participants.

Nick mentioned his friend's Tai-Chi site, which is generated from markdown. Cici (the Tai-Chi instructor) edits the markdown from github's Web-based editor, and when he saves it the site is automatically refreshed. The clip art all comes from a single OTF font, so he can pick relevant illustrations of the forms he's teaching that session. It's an interesting midpoint in the accessibility and technical resilience sense.

Chat

We all talked about the #permacomputing channel on Libera IRC, which hosts some of the luminaries who coined the term "permacomputing". Clients are a mess, and nobody remembers how they set theirs up, but wyrl and Devine Lu Linvega are on there.

We exchanged Signal IDs (and those who have whatsapp), and Nick got gurk working on his pinebook pro for TUI access to Signal.
contents.content:
## Text Adventures

Nick shared some PunyInform work he did with the CS department at University of Minnesota Duluth.  Their cybersecurity programme uses a text adventure written by postgraduates to test undergraduates' ability to exploit physical security vulnerabilities.

- [Live playable game](https://lars.d.umn.edu/one_night_in_sf/)
- [source code](https://github.com/UMDLARS/one_night_in_sf)

## Cameras

Nick gave Margot a spare Cisco/NXP digital camera from circa 2012 to play with, in case it was useful.  It has a glorious flip-out USB 2.0 plug, and a dastardly mini-HDMI socket.  It also runs off AA batteries (packaged separately, so the alkaline crust was contained in the shrinkwrap!).  It doesn't expose live video through the USB port, but perhaps the HDMI port could be a way to get a video stream.

## Printer

Dan brought the printer back out, and we learned that it was possibly running some sort of embedded Linux inside.  There are hopes of an exploit to get into the thing, but also there are approaches to defeat the self-disabling features of the cartridges themselves: 

The printer hosts its own WiFi network in the hall, which you need to switch to in order to poke at the submission port.  It runs its own service called "HP GGW", which was easily crashed in fuzz testing.

We talked about [various vegetable pigments](https://illustratorsproject.com/2023/01/06/artists-diy-making-natural-inks-from-plants-and-vegetables/) to make custom inks (as inkcap mushrooms are too toxic to work with casually just yet).

## CMS

Ana looked into alternatives that were more distributed, but the  project seems to be in a suspicious state regarding licensing and governance. This group would likely find raw git and markdown comfortable, but it presents an accessibility barrier to incoming participants.

Nick mentioned [his friend's Tai-Chi site](https://cicicisse.github.io/tai-chi/), which is generated [from markdown](https://github.com/cicicisse/tai-chi).  Cici (the Tai-Chi instructor) edits the markdown from github's Web-based editor, and when he saves it the site is automatically refreshed.  The clip art all comes from a single OTF font, so he can pick relevant illustrations of the forms he's teaching that session.  It's an interesting midpoint in the accessibility and technical resilience sense.

## Chat

We all talked about the `#permacomputing` channel on [Libera IRC](https://libera.chat), which hosts some of the luminaries who coined the term "permacomputing".  Clients are a mess, and nobody remembers how they set theirs up, but wyrl and Devine Lu Linvega are on there.

We exchanged Signal IDs (and those who have whatsapp), and Nick got `gurk` working on his pinebook pro for TUI access to Signal.

contents.title: HTML Day
contents.content_html:
The day is lined up with workshops and open projector sessions and is free to attend. Everyone is invited and no technical skills required, just a curiosity about HTML :)

More information and RSVP link can be found here: html.leaflet.pub
contents.description_html:
This year, we are teaming up with art & tech collective Cranberry Lemonade to host London’s HTML Day on the 2nd of August at Newspeak House, E2 7DG

Tags: event

metadata.description:
CMS for [permacomputing-club](https://london.permacomputing.net/ )
GitHub: https://github.com/anmeisel/permacomputing-club

# Guide:

### 1. Try to keep images under 400 KB

### 2. Fill in the **Title** field as the post's slug generation relies on this

### 3. Refer to [are.na's guide to markdown](https://help.are.na/docs/getting-started/blocks/adding-blocks#formatting-text) for text formatting

### 4. Optional Styling and Metadata –

You can personalise the appearance and metadata of your post by including any of the following special keys in the **Description** field. Each key should be followed by the relevant value on the same line.

- Tags: Add relevant keywords to help categorise and improve the discoverability of your post.
Example: "Tags: permacomputing, DIY, low-tech"

- Colour: Define a background colour for your post using a hex code.
Example: "Colour: #F0F8FF"

- Border: Define a border colour for your post using a hex code.
Example: "Border: #CCCCCC"

- Author: Add your name or pseudonym to be displayed as the post’s author.
Example: "Author: Alex"

- Pin: Use "Pin: top" if you want your post to stay pinned at the top of the feed.
Example: "Pin: top"

Notes:

- The description keys are not case-sensitive, but they must be written with the colon, and each should appear on its own line within the description. 

- The website polls for are.na data every 10 minutes, so when you add or delete a block, it might take some time for the frontend to update.

- Take a look at the source code on GitHub and go through its readme to understand how this is used as our CMS! :)

This is a space to collaborate and discuss how hardware and software can prioritise adaptability, transparency and care. At a time when harmful tech practices like AI are dominating culture, we want to build a community in opposition to this. permacomputing.net/principles.
